title: Eating & Drinking in Central London
name: Eating & Drinking in Central London
description:
A Map by Despitz

A selective guide to restaurants, cafes, and pubs in the heart of the nation's capitol.

properties.name: Little Bay
properties.description: Posted by Despitz EC1R 3AL London"An odd little place, with a ridiculous look: Euro-cheap red chairs, gold painted duct work, homemade gems of lamps, a tortured fabric ceiling, glazed red walls, a huge cast of Zeus\'s head, and so on. The cooking, which ranges from down-home English (haddock with mashed potatoes and sorrel) to Mediterranean (artichoke, chorizo and greens) is neither inventive nor exciting, but it is consistently good, and - by contemporary London standards - astonishingly inexpensive: about 0 for two, with wine." -The New York Times, May 8, 2005

properties.name: Marylebone Farmer's Market
properties.description: Posted by DespitzOpen Sundays until around 1pm.

properties.name: Mela
properties.description: Posted by Despitz152 Shaftesbury Avenue, London

properties.name: Moro for a popular tapas scene
properties.description: Posted by Despitz 34 Exmouth Market, EC1R 4QE, London England"This Spanish-style restaurant features good, reasonably priced tapas, and equally good full meals; the seasonings are strong and well applied. The Spanish-influenced takeout shop next door, Brindisa, is well-stocked and interesting." -The New York Times, May 8, 2005

properties.name: The Eagle for a hearty steak sandwich
properties.description: Posted by Despitz 159 Farringdon Road, EC1, London, England"Said to be London\'s original gastropub...This glossy painted place is funky as can be - it would appear that no two tables or chairs are alike - but the cooking is done to order and done very, very well. The menu changes daily, but if the roast pollock with chickpeas and aioli, and the duck with sherry and coriander were any indication, it\'s all good. There is only one dessert, a custard tart: get one." The New York Times, May 8, 2005
